Auditing:  Chromascape at Piedmont is focused on manufacturing quality product in a manner safe to the site, the community, and the business.  The site policies, training, and documentation requirements based on OSHA PSM and RMP guidelines are in place and will be audited in accordance with the regulations at the required frequency or higher.  Reporting and review of issues or events that arise related to safety and quality at the site are also documented with the Chromascape corporate Incident Reporting system (KPA).  This system requires assessment of events, identification and assignment of corrective items, and tracking of those items to completion.  

In addition to the audits required by internal site and corporate guidelines, we are regularly visited, inspected, and/or audited by regulatory agencies at their discretion.

Emergency Response:  Our operators are trained to identify unusual occurrences.  In the event of an incident on the plant site, the Piedmont Emergency Response Plan provides guidance on the actions to take.  As mentioned previously, in the case of release or fire, the operator or observer in the plant will notify all employees that an event has occurred.  

If the incident is within plant control a response plan will be developed.  If not, the emergency team lead (Piedmont Safety Manager) on site will order Shelter in Place with the plant population.  Operators will shut down transfer and reactor systems as they evacuate the operating portions of the plant.  All employees and on-stie contractors will Shelter in Place in designated areas on the site.  Designated employees will call for fire and emergency services via 911.  If needed, Chromascape management will summon emergency response contractors and will advise emergency responders of the known hazards and follow their guidance.

ont is to produce quality products and to produce them safely.  We have systems in place that are designed to prevent accidents to safeguard our employees, our community, and our environment.  Following is a partial listing of the safeguards that we employ in our everyday activities.

Design: This site was acquired from another business entity in 2022.   Since that time, we have used best engineering practices to ensure our systems would operate as intended.  All changes or additions to the processes now undergo a formal review and approval procedure (Management of Change).  This triggers hazard analysis and design safety reviews as necessary.  We have concrete dikes to catch any spilled materials.

Valve systems are designed with keyed locks to ensure that valves are operated as required for the process. 

On a regular schedule a site walk-through is conducted to review critical valve positions, valve locks, detection of leaks inside and outside of dikes, and the  status of the plant site in general.   If we find a valve, pipe, tank, or pump that might fail and allow a release or an incident, we will correct it immediately.

Maintenance:  We have formal mechanical integrity and preventative maintenance programs in place.  Tank inspections and preventative tasks for critical equipment identified with site Process Hazard Analyses are in place, and operators recheck equipment after maintenance has been completed before operating it.  

Safe Operations:  Our employees are essential to the safe operation of our plant.  Their training, their experience, their observations, and their knowledge of how to respond to situations is the basis of safe operations.  These people apply their knowledge and training in their everyday actions.  All activities at the Piedmont  plant  from unloading tank trucks to storage and processing vessels  are restricted to trained, designated employees.

Scenarios with Flammables:  We have materials at the Chromascape Piedmont facility that are flammable.  These other flammable materials, however, are not regulated under RMP.  Regardless, we have systems in place for these flammable materials that are designed to prevent accidents and to respond to accidents if they occur.

Chromascape Piedmont has policies and safeguards to prevent releases and minimize hazards from flammable materials.  Where flammable materials are stored or processed, vessels and piping are grounded to minimize static or electrical ignition such as from lightning strikes. In addition, vessels are equipped with conservation vents with flame arrestors to prevent venting and mitigate the impact of a potential fire. 

In the event of a fire on the plant site, our employees are equipped with fire-fighting equipment and are trained to evaluate the magnitude of the fire and if it is within their capability, to fight it until outside assistance arrives.  

Accident History:  In the past five years, this facility has had no incidents with RMP regulated materials causing an offsite consequence.

stewardship and safety programs, we recognize the hazards of handling and processing formaldehyde.  Our handling and processing of formaldehyde takes the hazards of the material into consideration.  We receive tank truck shipments of formaldehyde solution which are transferred into a stabilizer solution of water and acetone.  The vessel the formaldehyde is transferred into is an atmospheric tank with conservation vent to minimize pressure, emissions, and protect the tank from vacuum during transfer to the reaction vessel.

Offsite Consequence Analysis:
Worst Case Scenario  Toxic Chemical Analysis of our processes showed the Worst Case Scenario to be the sudden and complete loss of a truck of formaldehyde solution.  The only safety precautions that Risk Management allows to be considered in the Worst Case Scenario are passive mitigation devices.  In our case, the stabilized formaldehyde solution is surrounded by concrete dike containment.  The suppliers tank truck of formaldehyde solution, however, sits in a separate containment area outside of the tank dike.  This tank truck containment area is currently a portable containment apparatus, but there is a project in place to install a permanent concrete curbing containment area.  

The contents of a ruptured or leaking truck would empty into the contained unloading pad, which would drain into a sump or be pumped into the adjacent tank concrete dike until transferred into sealed bulk containers by Chromascape employees. This routing would limit the surface area from which formaldehyde could evaporate.

Executive Summary 

Chromascape is a chemical manufacturing company with headquarters based in Independence, OH.  We produce products for several diverse industries, including paper/corrugated board manufacturing, landscape mulch/media, printing inks, coatings, building products, and pavement construction.  

The Piedmont plant manufactures products for building products including adhesives and resins for the wood composites and laminates markets.  The portion of the plant that is covered by Risk Management makes Urea Formaldehyde Resins that are sold to companies in the above markets.  The facility has been in operation for 12 years total, but under Chromascape ownership since 2022.  

OSHA regulations (Process Safety Management) also apply to the site and require that consideration of layers of protection be included during design, before startup, and to continue through operations and training of all employees.   These same elements are also used to fulfill RMP requirements for the site.  Some of these elements have been in place at the site, but a rigorous review and Process Hazard Analysis have identified additional safeguards and administrative controls that need to be in place at Piedmont.  These additional administrative components and equipment safeguards are currently being implemented to ensure that the site meets the requirements of both Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs.   

The Chromascape Piedmont plant site currently uses one raw material that is covered under Risk Management: Formaldehyde Solution.  

Formaldehyde Solution:
Colorless liquid with a pungent odor
Formaldehyde solutions are denser than water
Formaldehyde vapor is similar to that of air
Contact with the eyes can result in severe burns 
Contact with the skin can cause burns, blistering, or allergic reactions
Inhalation can cause severe respiratory distress and other potential health issues
